summary_points: 1. George Kurtz's annual base salary will be $1,100,000, and his target incentive compensation will be 135%, effective February 1, 2025.
2.  The filing is an 8-K Current Report, filed on April 25, 2025, reporting events that occurred on April 23, 2025.
3.  CrowdStrike's incentive compensation for named executive officers is governed by their Corporate Incentive Plan, filed as an exhibit to their June 1, 2023, Form 10-Q.

1. Public Service Enterprise Group Inc.'s (PSEG) annual shareholder meeting on April 22, 2025, resulted in the election of all management's nominees to the board of directors and the approval of an advisory vote on executive compensation; however, proposed amendments to eliminate supermajority voting requirements failed to receive the necessary 80% affirmative vote.
2.  The vote counts for Proposal 1 (Election of Directors) ranged from approximately 348,742,278 to 360,461,785 "votes for," with "votes against" ranging from approximately 1,160,589 to 24,858,567.

3. The failure to pass Proposal 3 (eliminating supermajority voting requirements) may impact PSEG's ability to execute certain business combinations, remove directors, or amend bylaws, potentially hindering future strategic initiatives.

1. Charter Communications, Inc. held its 2025 Annual Meeting of Stockholders on April 22, 2025, at which stockholders approved the Charter Communications, Inc. 2025 Employee Stock Purchase Plan, effective the same day.
2.  At the Annual Meeting, 149,371,806 shares voted in favor of the 2025 Employee Stock Purchase Plan, while 250,261 shares voted against it and 63,894 abstained.
3. The 2025 Employee Stock Purchase Plan allows for the issuance of up to 1,500,000 shares of Class A common stock.
1. Robert Gamgort transitioned from Executive Chairman to non-employee Chairman of Keurig Dr Pepper Inc. on April 24, 2025.
2.  Keurig Dr Pepper Inc.'s Board of Directors expanded to ten members with the addition of Michael Van de Ven and Lawson Whiting as independent directors on April 24, 2025.
3. Keurig Dr Pepper Inc.'s 2025 proxy statement, filed April 25, 2025, details the compensation for Gamgort, Van de Ven, and Whiting.

1. Westinghouse Air Brake Technologies Corporation (WAB) entered into an Amended and Restated Credit Agreement on April 23, 2025, refinancing existing credit and term agreements, creating a revolving credit facility of up to $2.0 billion and a delayed draw term loan facility of $725.0 million.
2.  The new credit agreement includes an optional incremental facility of up to an additional $1.0 billion, subject to certain conditions.

3. The interest rate for borrowings under the amended agreement is variable and depends on the company's leverage ratio and public credit rating, with rates ranging from 1.000% to 1.750% for SOFR/RFR-based borrowings and 0.000% to 0.750% for Alternate Base Rate based borrowings; the agreement matures on April 23, 2030.
1. Weyerhaeuser's net earnings decreased by 27% year-over-year in Q1 2025, falling to $83 million.
2.  A Chinese import ban on US logs, effective March 2025, poses a risk to Weyerhaeuser's Timberlands segment.
3.  In Q1 2025, Weyerhaeuser refinanced debt, repaying $200 million in debentures and issuing a new $300 million term loan maturing in March 2030.

1. Motorola Solutions, Inc. signed a new $2.25 billion revolving credit agreement on April 25, 2025, with an option to increase it to $2.75 billion, maturing on April 25, 2030, with the possibility of two one-year extensions.
2.  The company terminated its previous revolving credit agreement, dated March 24, 2021, with no outstanding borrowings or early termination penalties.

3. The new credit agreement includes a financial covenant requiring Motorola Solutions to maintain a specified leverage ratio and restrictive covenants limiting certain actions, such as creating liens and entering into sale and leaseback transactions.
1. On April 24, 2025, ONEOK, Inc.'s board of directors declared a quarterly dividend of $1.03 per share, unchanged from the previous quarter.
2. This represents an annualized dividend of $4.12 per share.
3.  The dividend is payable on May 15, 2025, to shareholders of record at the close of business on May 5, 2025.
1. On April 25, 2025, HP Inc. issued $1 billion in notes, split between $500 million of 5.400% notes maturing in 2030 and $500 million of 6.100% notes maturing in 2035.
2. The 2035 notes offer a higher interest rate (6.100%) than the 2030 notes (5.400%).

3. HP Inc. has the option to redeem the notes at a price calculated using a formula based on the current Treasury Rate, with redemption dates set for March 25, 2030, and January 25, 2035, respectively.
1. Healthpeak's net income applicable to common shares increased by $35,887,000 year-over-year (2025 vs. 2024).
2.  The company realized $674,000,000 from the sale of 59 outpatient medical buildings in Q1 2025.
3. A 1% change in interest rates could impact the fair value of Healthpeak's derivative instruments by up to $50 million.
1. Amphenol's Q1 2025 net sales increased significantly, up 48% in USD and 49% in constant currencies compared to Q1 2024.
2.  As of April 22, 2025, Amphenol had repurchased $224.8 million worth of its common stock in 2025 and $1,311.6 million remaining authorization under its 2024 Stock Repurchase Program.
3.  Amphenol increased its unsecured revolving credit facility by $500 million to $3 billion, maturing in March 2029.
1. Aptiv PLC's Annual General Meeting of Shareholders was held on April 23, 2025, resulting in the election of several directors and the approval of Ernst & Young LLP as auditors.

2.  Shareholder votes on director elections ranged from 177,674,519 "For" votes (Paul M. Meister) to 196,536,302 "For" votes (Vasumati P. Jakkal), with varying levels of "Against" and "Abstain" votes across the nominees.

3.  Aptiv's named executive officer compensation was approved on an advisory basis by shareholders, with 177,675,761 votes in favor, 18,766,650 against, and 781,394 abstentions, plus 7,017,516 broker non-votes.
1. Revvity, Inc. shareholders approved amendments to the company's Articles of Organization to implement a majority voting standard for specified corporate actions, effective April 23, 2025.

2.  At the April 22, 2025 shareholder meeting, the proposal to approve executive compensation received 92,835,062 votes in favor and 8,444,564 votes against, indicating significant opposition to the compensation plan.
3. A shareholder proposal regarding the ability to call special shareholder meetings was approved at the April 22, 2025 meeting.
1. At Edison International's April 24, 2025 annual shareholder meeting, a shareholder proposal regarding severance pay arrangements failed to receive majority support.
2.  Linda G. Stuntz received significantly fewer votes (288,832,208) than other director nominees, who each received over 295,000,000 votes.
3. The amendment and restatement of the EIX 2007 Performance Incentive Plan was adopted, despite receiving less than a majority of votes cast *for* the proposal.
1. Lam Research Corp's revenue increased 8% year-over-year to $4,720,175,000 in the quarter ended March 30, 2025, primarily driven by Foundry market segment growth.
2.  Between June 30, 2024, and March 30, 2025, Lam Research Corp's cash and equivalents decreased by $400 million.
3.  Lam Research Corp. faces a potential tax liability fluctuation of up to $211 million over the next year (as of April 25, 2025).
1. On April 23, 2025, Domino's Pizza, Inc. shareholders approved charter amendments eliminating supermajority voting provisions and granting shareholders the right to call special meetings.
2. At the 2025 annual shareholder meeting, 90.29% of outstanding shares participated in the vote.
3. A shareholder proposal regarding lowering the ownership threshold for calling a special meeting to 15% was rejected by shareholders.
1. On April 24, 2025, Fastenal Company's Board approved a two-for-one forward stock split, effective May 21, 2025, increasing the number of authorized Common Stock shares to 1,600,000,000.

2. At the April 24, 2025 annual shareholder meeting, the advisory vote to approve named executive officer compensation passed with 438,459,188 votes for, 28,537,462 votes against, and 1,601,891 abstentions.
3. All eleven director nominees were elected at the April 24, 2025 shareholder meeting, though significant numbers of votes were cast against several nominees (ranging from 679,254 to 33,524,708).
1. Aon plc's Q1 2025 revenue increased 16% year-over-year to $4.7 billion, driven primarily by acquisitions and organic growth, despite a negative currency impact.
2.  Diluted earnings per share decreased by $0.92 to $4.43 in Q1 2025 compared to Q1 2024.
3.  A three-year restructuring plan is expected to result in $1 billion in cumulative costs but yield $350 million in annualized expense savings by the end of 2026.
1. Las Vegas Sands Corp. abandoned its pursuit of casino licenses in New York and Nassau, citing lower-than-expected ROI and seeking buyers for the acquired properties.
2.  The company's Marina Bay Sands Expansion Project, with a total estimated cost of $8 billion, is expected to open in January 2031.
3.  As of April 22, 2025, the company increased its share repurchase authorization by $900 million, to a total of $2 billion.
1. Tyler Technologies' Q1 2025 revenue increased 10% year-over-year, driven by a 20% rise in subscription revenue.
2.  The company's acquisition of MyGov LLC for $18.2 million in January 2025 and potential future acquisitions may necessitate debt financing or equity issuance.
3.  As of March 31, 2025, Tyler Technologies faces a lawsuit with potential costs exceeding $15 million.

1. American Express issued $4.6 billion in notes on April 25, 2025, comprised of $1.6 billion in 4.731% notes due April 25, 2029, $1.5 billion in 5.016% notes due April 25, 2031, $1.5 billion in 5.667% notes due April 25, 2036, and $400 million in floating rate notes due April 25, 2029.
2.  These notes were issued under a senior indenture dated August 1, 2007, and supplemented on February 12, 2021, and May 1, 2023.
3. The legal opinion confirms the notes are valid and binding obligations of American Express, enforceable according to their terms, subject to general principles of equity and bankruptcy laws.
1. Phillips 66's Q1 2025 net income decreased by $361 million year-over-year to $487 million.
2. The company acquired EPIC Y-Grade GP, LLC and EPIC Y-Grade, LP for $2.2 billion on April 1, 2025.
3.  The planned closure of the Los Angeles Refinery in Q4 2025 will result in $246 million of accelerated depreciation.

1. J.B. Hunt Transport Services, Inc.'s annual stockholder meeting on April 24, 2025, resulted in the election of directors, approval of an advisory resolution on executive compensation, and ratification of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as the independent auditor for 2025.
2.  Director James L. Robo received significantly fewer "For" votes (81,124,500) than other directors, with a substantially higher number of "Against" votes (8,826,077) compared to the others.
3.  No additional business matters were discussed at the April 24, 2025, meeting.
1. J.B. Hunt's first-quarter 2025 net earnings decreased by 7.6% year-over-year to $117.74 million.
2. The company repurchased $234.1 million of its common stock during the first quarter of 2025, and as of April 25, 2025, has $650.2 million remaining for future repurchases.
3. J.B. Hunt anticipates spending between $500 million and $700 million on net capital expenditures in 2025.
1. Eastman Chemical Co.'s Q1 2025 sales revenue decreased by $20 million (1%) compared to Q1 2024, primarily due to lower sales volume in the Fibers and Advanced Materials segments.
2.  The company anticipates $550 million in capital expenditures for 2025, focused on growth initiatives including molecular recycling and site modernization.
3. As of March 31, 2025, Eastman had $285 million in commercial paper borrowings, a significant increase from zero at the end of 2024.
1. LyondellBasell's Q1 2025 net income dropped 62% year-over-year to $175 million, primarily due to the cessation of Houston refinery operations in February 2025.
2. The company's marketable securities decreased significantly from $2,610 million to $1,161 million between December 31, 2024, and March 31, 2025.
3. LyondellBasell expects to incur $215 million in shutdown costs for its European PO Joint Venture through 2027.
1. Halliburton experienced a 7% year-over-year decrease in total company revenue during Q1 2025, reaching $5.4 billion.
2.  Newly implemented tariffs (effective April 22, 2025) caused a 10% drop in crude oil prices since the end of Q1 2025, negatively impacting projected Q2 2025 earnings per share.
3.  Halliburton incurred $356 million in impairments and other charges during Q1 2025, including significant severance ($107 million) and asset impairment costs.
1. Schlumberger's Q1 2025 net income decreased 25% year-over-year to $797 million, driven partly by $158 million in severance charges.
2. The ChampionX acquisition, expected to close in Q2 or early Q3 2025, will result in ChampionX shareholders owning approximately 9% of SLB's outstanding common stock.
3.  SLB anticipates $242 million in intangible asset amortization expense for the remaining three quarters of 2025, extending through 2030.
1. Verizon's consolidated operating revenues increased by 1.5% year-over-year in Q1 2025, driven by growth in the Consumer segment.
2.  Verizon anticipates capital expenditures of $17.5 billion to $18.5 billion in 2025, potentially increasing due to the Frontier acquisition.
3.  As of March 31, 2025, Verizon's cash, cash equivalents, and restricted cash decreased by $1.863 billion compared to December 31, 2024.

1. Phillips 66 reported first-quarter 2025 earnings of $487 million ($1.18 per share), but an adjusted loss of $368 million ($0.90 per share) due to $246 million in pre-tax accelerated depreciation on the Los Angeles Refinery.
2.  Year-over-year (YoY)  pipeline throughput decreased by 55 million barrels per day (MB/D) to 370 MB/D as of March 31, 2025.
3.  A new gas processing plant in the Permian Basin is planned to commence operations in the first quarter of 2027.

1. CME Group Inc. secured a new $2.25 billion revolving credit facility (expandable to $3.25 billion) maturing April 23, 2030, and amended its existing $7 billion (expandable to $10 billion) 364-day facility.
2.  As of December 31, 2024, CME Group was contractually obligated to maintain a Consolidated Tangible Net Worth of at least $800,000,000.
3.  CME Group's agreements are fixed to rules published before April 25, 2025, meaning any subsequent rule changes will not affect these contracts.

1. Kevin J. Wheeler will transition from Chairman and Chief Executive Officer to Executive Chairman of A. O. Smith Corporation, effective July 1, 2025, with Stephen M. Shafer becoming the new Chief Executive Officer.
2.  Stephen M. Shafer, the new CEO, joined A. O. Smith in March 2024, previously serving as president of the Automotive and Aerospace Solutions Division for 3M Company.

3.  A. O. Smith Corporation identifies several future risks, including negative impacts from international tariffs, softening water heater demand, global inflationary pressures, and supply chain disruptions.
1. CenterPoint Energy, Inc. announced the commencement of cash tender offers on April 25, 2025, totaling up to $1 billion to repurchase its and its subsidiary's outstanding senior notes.
2.  The tender offers aim to reduce CenterPoint Energy's and CenterPoint Energy Resources Corp.'s outstanding indebtedness by $1 billion (excluding accrued interest).
3.  The tender offers, if fully subscribed, will be settled using CenterPoint Energy’s and CERC’s existing cash and commercial paper borrowings by May 28, 2025, at the latest.
1. Colgate-Palmolive acquired Care TopCo Pty Ltd, owner of Prime100 pet food, in Q2 2025.
2.  Net sales decreased by 3.1% year-over-year in Q1 2025, primarily due to negative foreign exchange impacts.
3. The company estimates $200 million in additional 2025 costs from tariffs and a similar range of potential losses from ongoing legal proceedings.

1. E. William Parsley III will cease to be PNC Financial Services Group's Chief Operating Officer on July 1, 2025, transitioning to an Executive Advisor role until December 31, 2025, after which he will receive payments and benefits under the company's Executive Severance Plan.

2.  At the April 23, 2025 shareholder meeting, the advisory vote to approve the compensation of named executive officers received 93.05% in favor, 6.95% against, with 0.9% abstaining or broker non-votes.
3.  The 13 director nominees named in the corporation’s proxy statement were elected at the April 23, 2025 shareholder meeting.

1. Colgate-Palmolive's net sales decreased by 3.1% in the first quarter of 2025, while organic sales increased by 1.4%, indicating underlying growth despite a negative impact from foreign exchange and private label pet volume.
2.  GAAP earnings per share (EPS) increased by 2% to $0.85 in Q1 2025, compared to $0.83 in Q1 2024, while the non-GAAP (Base Business) EPS increased by 6% to $0.91.

3.  Colgate-Palmolive updated its full-year 2025 financial guidance, predicting low single-digit net sales growth (including a low single-digit negative impact from foreign exchange) and organic sales growth of 2% to 4%.

1. Dow Inc. experienced a significant year-over-year decrease in net income from $516 million in Q1 2024 to a net loss of $307 million in Q1 2025, largely due to a $207 million pretax charge for restructuring.
2.  A pending court ruling could result in a $1 billion gain for Dow Inc. by the end of 2025, although this is subject to appeal.
3. Dow Inc. is strategically reviewing European assets worth approximately $275 million in response to macroeconomic volatility as of April 24th, 2025.
1. AbbVie's Q1 2025 net revenues were $13.343 billion, an 8.4% increase year-over-year on a reported basis and a 9.8% increase on an operational basis (as of April 25, 2025).
2.  Global Skyrizi net revenues increased by 70.5% year-over-year on a reported basis to $3.425 billion in Q1 2025, while global Humira net revenues decreased by 50.6% to $1.121 billion.

3. AbbVie raised its full-year 2025 adjusted diluted EPS guidance from $11.99-$12.19 to $12.09-$12.29, incorporating a $0.13 per share unfavorable impact from acquired IPR&D and milestones expense incurred in Q1 2025.
1. HCA Healthcare reported $18.321 billion in revenue for the first quarter of 2025, a year-over-year increase compared to $17.339 billion in Q1 2024.
2.  HCA Healthcare repurchased 7.762 million shares of its common stock for $2.506 billion during the first quarter of 2025.

3. The company reaffirmed its 2025 estimated guidance ranges (issued January 24, 2025), which include assumptions about volume growth, a stable operating environment, and the impacts of the 2024 hurricanes and healthcare policy.

1. Walgreens Boots Alliance, Inc. repaid its $1 billion senior unsecured delayed draw term loan credit agreements due in November 2026 and January 2026 using funds from a new $2.5 billion accounts receivable securitization facility on April 24, 2025.
2.  All commitments under the repaid loan agreements were terminated on April 24, 2025.
3. The new accounts receivable securitization facility provides an initial borrowing capacity of up to $2.5 billion.

1. Schlumberger Limited/NV's first-quarter 2025 revenue of $8.49 billion decreased 3% year-over-year, primarily due to a sharper-than-expected slowdown in Mexico and a slow start in Saudi Arabia and offshore Africa, offset partially by higher activity in other regions.
2.  First-quarter 2025 GAAP EPS decreased 22% year-over-year to $0.58, while non-GAAP EPS (excluding charges and credits) decreased 4% to $0.72.

3.  The company anticipates $2.3 billion in capital investment for the full year 2025 (excluding any impact from the ChampionX acquisition), compared to $2.6 billion in 2024; the ChampionX acquisition is expected to close in the second or early third quarter of 2025, pending regulatory approval.
1. Charter added 514,000 mobile lines in Q1 2025, while internet and video customer losses decreased compared to the same period last year.
2.  Charter repurchased $802 million of its Class A common stock in Q1 2025, and as of March 31, 2025, had $2.7 billion of remaining share repurchase authority.
3. Charter incurred a $90 million impairment charge related to its Los Angeles Lakers regional sports network agreement in Q1 2025.

1. Charter Communications, Inc. reported a first-quarter 2025 revenue of $13.7 billion, a 0.4% year-over-year increase primarily driven by residential mobile service revenue growth of 33.5%, residential Internet revenue growth of 1.8%, and other revenue growth of 13.4%.
2.  First-quarter 2025 free cash flow increased to $1.6 billion, a significant jump from $358 million in the first quarter of 2024.

3. Charter anticipates full-year 2025 capital expenditures to reach approximately $12 billion, contingent on several factors including network evolution and expansion, supply chain timing, and growth in residential and commercial sectors.

1. LyondellBasell Industries N.V. reported a net income of $177 million for the quarter ended March 31, 2025, which was $0.21 per share higher than it would have been excluding identified items like exit costs from closing a Dutch joint venture.
2.  Compared to the same period in 2024, EBITDA decreased by $400 million, primarily due to planned and unplanned maintenance and higher energy costs.
3. LyondellBasell announced a $500 million Cash Improvement Plan to address macroeconomic volatility and strengthen financial results, indicating concern about continued industry downturn.
1. Fiserv's Q1 2025 net income increased by 16% year-over-year, reaching $116 million more than Q1 2024, primarily due to higher processing revenue.
2. Fiserv acquired Payfare Inc. and CCV Group B.V. in March 2025 for a total of $324 million.
3. Fiserv anticipates approximately $16 million in losses over the next year (from April 25, 2025) related to foreign exchange and interest rate hedging contracts.

1. Aon plc reported 16% total revenue growth for the quarter ended March 31, 2025, driven by the contribution from NFP, 5% organic revenue growth, and a 2% unfavorable impact from foreign currency translation.
2.  Free cash flow decreased significantly year-over-year in Q1 2025, falling from $261 million to $84 million, a 68% decrease.
3. The company expects an unfavorable impact on adjusted EPS of approximately $0.08 per share for the full year 2025 due to foreign currency translation if current rates remain stable.
1. Alphabet Inc. acquired Wiz for $32 billion, an all-cash transaction expected to close in 2026.
2.  Alphabet repurchased $15.3 billion of its shares in Q1 2025 and authorized a further $70 billion repurchase program in April 2025.
3. Alphabet has $17.3 billion in future lease payments for data centers commencing between 2025 and 2031.
1. Centene Corp's Q1 2025 adjusted diluted EPS was $2.90, a 28% year-over-year increase from Q1 2024.
2.  As of April 25th, 2025, Centene increased its 2025 premium and service revenue guidance by $6.0 billion, primarily due to Marketplace enrollment outperformance and Medicare Advantage retention.
3. Centene secured a five-year (with a two-year extension option) Medicaid managed care contract in Nevada, starting January 2026, and also won a contract for the state's Marketplace public option.
1. Centene Corp.'s managed care membership declined by 479,000 (2%) year-over-year as of March 31, 2025, while total revenues increased 15% to $46.6 billion for Q1 2025.
2. Centene anticipates $1.6 billion in net cash from dividends and capital expenditures ($615 million) for the remainder of 2025.

3.  As of March 5, 2025, Centene Corp. secured a new credit agreement with a $4 billion revolving credit facility and a $2 billion term loan, maturing March 5, 2030, subject to a quarterly debt-to-capital ratio covenant.
1. Republic Services acquired $826 million in environmental services businesses in Q1 2025, and plans to invest a further $1 billion in acquisitions throughout the year.

2.  Despite a 3.8% year-over-year revenue increase in Q1 2025, this was driven by increased yield, offsetting a volume decrease; the company also expects $10 million in restructuring charges in the remainder of 2025.

3.  Republic Services is contesting liability for $392 million in remediation costs at the West Lake Landfill Superfund site as of April 25, 2025, and had $62 million in outstanding borrowings as of March 31, 2025.
1. Intel recorded a $2.8 billion non-cash goodwill impairment charge in Q3 2025, primarily impacting Mobileye.
2. Intel's Q1 2025 net income was -$887 million, a significant year-over-year decrease.
3. Intel's 2024 Restructuring Plan, expected to be complete by Q4 2025, incurred a cumulative cost of $2.9 billion as of April 25, 2025.
1. Southwest Airlines reported a $149 million net loss in Q1 2025, a 35.5% year-over-year decrease despite record operating revenues.
2.  The airline projects flat to down 4% year-over-year unit revenue in Q2 2025, despite a 1-2% capacity increase, due to inflationary pressures increasing operating expenses by 3.5-5.5%.
3.  Southwest discontinued its fuel hedging program in Q1 2025 and doesn't plan to reinstate it before 2028.
1. On April 24, 2025, IQVIA Holdings Inc. amended its Certificate of Incorporation to exculpate certain officers from liability and remove obsolete provisions related to its board structure.

2. At the 2025 Annual Meeting of Stockholders (record date February 24, 2025),  a proposal concerning special stockholder meetings received significantly more "against" votes (86,013,439) than "for" votes (66,155,724).
3.  The appointment of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as IQVIA's independent registered public accounting firm for the year ending December 31, 2025, was ratified by stockholders.
1. At Eaton Corporation plc's April 23, 2025 Annual General Meeting, all shareholder proposals were approved.
2.  The election of twelve director nominees saw significant variation in "Against" votes, ranging from 774,162 to 19,543,678.
3. Proposal 3, advisory approval of executive compensation, received 285,077,494 "For" votes and 20,710,365 "Against" votes, indicating some shareholder dissent regarding executive pay.
1. Rollins, Inc. completed four acquisitions totaling $28.9 million in Q1 2025.
2. Rollins, Inc.'s Q1 2025 revenue increased 9.9% year-over-year to $822.5 million, despite a negative impact from currency fluctuations.
3. Rollins, Inc. anticipates a significant increase in interest expense in 2025, projecting $8-10 million for Q2 alone.
1. Verisign's .com and .net domain name registrations decreased by 1.5% year-over-year to 169.8 million as of March 31, 2025.
2.  Verisign refinanced $500 million in debt, replacing notes due April 1, 2025 with new notes due June 1, 2032.
3. As of March 31, 2025, Verisign had $792.7 million remaining available under its authorized common stock repurchase program.
